Members of the anti-Syrian majority in the government struck a defiant tone, saying neither opposition protests nor assassinations would topple the elected government.
But many Lebanese worry that after the mourning for Gemayel passes the government will face difficult problems with limited political resources.
NPR's Peter Kenyon reports from Beirut.
